    Question again proposed.

    The Chairman: Mr Chin had the floor yesterday when he was interrupted at the

Column: 420

Moment of Interruption. Mr Chin, will you please resume.

    Mr Chin Harn Tong (Aljunied): Mr Speaker, Sir, at the end of yesterday's session, I was commenting on the need to avoid unnecessary duplication of work in the Industrial Relations Division, with particular reference to the Preventive Mediation Labour Assessment Section and the Conciliation Section. As it is, I am given to understand that the Preventive Mediation Labour Assessment Section will, for instance, at the request of an employer, try its best to prevent an outbreak of dispute between the employer and his workers. If the attempt at prevention fails and a dispute takes place, the Preventive Mediation Section hands over the case to the Conciliation Section. To me, it seems more logical that the Preventive Mediation Section should continue with the handling of the case until its conclusion one way or the other.

Column: 421



    Under the existing arrangement, the relevant officer in the Conciliation Section will have to spend more time briefing himself as to what was done by the Preventive Mediation Section. I think that is a needless waste of time. I hope the Ministry can make some arrangement to ensure that the Preventive Mediation Section can also do the work of the Conciliation Section and vice versa.

    Then there is the section captioned as the "NON-UNIONISED WORKERS SECTION." The superficial impression thereby created on the public is that the Ministry conscientiously looks after the welfare of workers not represented by trade unions. But I have been given to understand that the officers in that Section are not too enthusiastic in their work. Recently a few workers who went to that section, with a view to invoking the Minister's power of reinstatement under section 14 of the Employment Act, found themselves being made to wait for more than two hours before they were attended to.

    I am not happy with the staffing of the Non-unionised Workers Section. I am given to understand that the officers of the Section are certified interpreters. Undoubtedly, these interpreters are competent to advise non-unionised workers on their nights under the Employment Act, as they have been and are probably still attached to the Labour Court which enforces the provisions of the Employment Act. But among the workers who seek the assistance of the Non-unionised Workers Section, there are some who require advice and assistance on their rights under some other statutory enactments such as the Industrial Relations Act. My concern is whether the officers manning the Non-unionised Workers Section have the relevant experience and training to give the wide range of advice and assistance they are called upon to give on behalf of the Ministry.

    It is all very well to promise about highpowered personnel overseeing the conduct of the industrial relations by the Ministry. But if little or insufficient attention is paid to both the professional and the human aspects of the Ministry's performance of its services to the public, the promise regarding the

Column: 422

Industrial Relations Division becomes rather hollow.

    Mr Sia Khoon Seong (Moulmein): I am not speaking, Sir.

    The Minister of State for Labour (Mr Sia Kah Hui): Sir, I do not know whether Members could recollect what the Member for Aljunied said last night, but I hope that my reply will throw light on it.

    The Industrial Relations Division reorganised last year comprises three sections: the Conciliation Section, the Preventive Mediation and Labour Assessment Section, and the Registry of Trade Unions. The Conciliation Section comprises two units, one for disputes involving unionised workers and the other for disputes involving non-unionised workers. The Registry of Trade Unions retains its old title as an integral section of the Industrial Relations Division. The Preventive Mediation and Labour Assessment Section is a new one.

    Despite the unsettling effect of the global recession and the resultant spate of retrenchments, there were only 1 8 minor work stoppages and seven strikes in 1975 as compared to 28 minor work stoppages and 10 strikes in 1974. The number of man-days lost in the strikes was 4,853 in 1975 as against 5.380 in 1974. Seen against the 709 labour dispute cases involving 92,339 unionised employees dealt with by the Industrial Relations Division, Members will agree that the number of industrial stoppages in 1975 is insignificantly small. This is primarily because most of these disputes were amicably settled through conciliation by the officers of the Industrial Relations Division. Only in 51 cases did the parties fail to reach agreement through conciliation, and the unresolved issues were referred to the Industrial Arbitration Count. For the whole year of 1975 the Division also handled 1,191 dispute cases involving 3,437 non-unionised workers. Of these, 1 .079 cases were settled resulting in obtaining a total sum of $202,473 for the workers.

    The maintenance of industrial peace and stability in 1975 as in previous years was in

Column: 423

large measure due to the good sense and reasonableness displayed by both management and trade unions and the hard work put in by the staff of the Industrial Relations Division. The Ministry is determined to improve and upgrade the competence and skill of the officers in the Industrial Relations Division. One of the objectives in reorganising the Division is to ensure that the staff are given an all-round training in the various aspects of industrial relations work. In this connection, the experienced staff in the former Industrial Relations Section are being retained to provide continuity, while new Administrative Officers are being trained in conciliation and mediation work. The initial training of these new officers in the Division consists of orientation, briefing and learning at first hand from actual conciliation proceedings. They are subsequently given close guidance and supervision in their duties.

    I am sure the Member for Aljunied, being a trained industrial relations man himself, will agree that in conciliation and mediation work no amount of formal training can substitute for on-the-job training. It takes time for a new officer to acquire the necessary specialist knowledge in order to become the skilful negotiator. mediator or assessment officer. It also takes time for the new officer to earn the confidence and respect of both managers and trade union leaders.

    The Member for Aljunied may wish to know that the Ministry is looking into the possibility of re-establishing a departmental service to deal with industrial relations and labour matters: provided, of course, that with such a service the Ministry can build up a corps of trained and experienced industrial relations and labour officers.

    With regard to the other matters raised, I would like to clarify the function of the Preventive Mediation Section. Briefly, the work involved would be to deal with brewing industrial problems, that is, problems of day-to-day relations which could escalate into serious labour disputes, and follow-up action in the form of advice to management on

Column: 424

dispute cases which are known to have been caused by inadequate grievance procedure, poor management-worker communication and personnel mismanagement. In addition the Section also deals with alleged victimisation and wrongful dismissal cases as well as complaints of alleged unjustified retrenchment. Since the officers of the Preventive Mediation and Labour Assessment Section also come under the Industrial Relations Division, it has been possible for the assignment of work to be kept flexible and in no instance has there been any duplication of work between these two sections. The Preventive Mediation Section has consistently handled a case until its conclusion and has not handed any case to the Conciliation Section. Accordingly, when an impending dispute is handled by an officer in the Preventive Mediation Section, he will follow through the case until the dispute is resolved, even in the event that the dispute does escalate into industrial action.

    With regard to the Non-Unionised Workers' Section, the labelling is simply for the convenience of workers who visit the Ministry with their problems, so that they would know where to go and to whom they should present their problems in the first instance. It must be pointed out that the staff in this Unit are competent to advise unionised workers as well as those who are not unionised. There are in this Unit one post of Administrative Assistant, four posts of Executive Officers and four posts of Certificated Interpreters who together cover all Chinese dialects, in addition to Tamil and Malay.

    The Member also mentioned the case of a few workers who, seeking reinstatement, had to wait for hours before they were attended to. This is most unfortunate. If the Member were to give me more details, the case could be looked into.

    Industrial accidents resulting in death or permanent disabilities to workmen have occurred too frequently in our island Republic in the last few years of our industrial expansion. It is a sad fact of life that the victims of such accidents invariably come from the low income group. It is not difficult to imagine the heart pangs and anguish such tragedies bring to the families of such victims and themselves, if they escape death only to become permanent cripples. Added to these are the mental agonies and anxieties regarding the future of their families.

    The plight of the families of such victims not only deserves our compassion and sympathy but also constantly reminds us of the need for accident prevention in workplaces through adequate occupational health and safety measures. This is a matter of paramount importance and concern for the Government, the employers and the trade unions in their common pursuit of workers' welfare and security.

    Surely some of these accidents could have been prevented if greater care had been exercised by all concerned in safety measures. Sad to say, some employers, particularly those who are contractors, are just not treating their workers as human beings. It is made to appear to them that the life of their workers is no more sacred than the life of a dog. They are more concerned with the raking of profits, of more and more profits. More safety measures mean cutting down the margin of their profits. Unfortunately, this nonchalant attitude towards the sacredness of life of the workers as shown by some of the unscrupulous employers is also prevalent among a handful of senior civil servants in change of economic planning and development. They are very conscious of financial cost factor in any economic activity. Occupational and safety measures are only to be maintained at their

Column: 426

absolute minimum level to save cost. To them the human cost is less important because, according to them, the human price we must pay for economic development is unavoidable, little realising that the economic losses due to accidents can be higher than the amount spent on additional safety measures. Such economic losses are in the form of workmen's compensation, medical costs, loss in productivity, etc.

    It is all the more important that both the Labour Ministry and the NTUC must relentlessly pursue occupational health and safety programmes to curb unnecessary deaths and maiming. It is heartening to note that this is being done. I must compliment the Senior Parliamentary Secretary (Labour) for his fearless attacks against employers, both in the public and private sectors, for not taking adequate safety measures to protect workers at their workplaces.

    In December 1975 regulations were introduced by the Labour Ministry to govern the effective running of Joint Safety Committees. This year on 1st March regulations governing safety officers were introduced. Equally important is the need for the Ministry of Labour to draw up programmes to ensure safer working environment to complement the new regulations that were recently introduced. I hope the 1975 statistics relating to industrial accidents is prompting the Ministry to initiate not only self-regulatory systems but also more scientific and systematic programmes to develop early warning methods of anticipating and preventing occurrences of accidents.

    Mr P. Govindaswamy (Anson): Mr Speaker, Sir, in the Memorandum on the Budget Estimates I observe that there has been an increase of 10 posts in the Factory Inspectorate for the purpose of setting up a new Shipbuilding and Repairing Inspections Section. In the past, I spoke a great deal about safety consciousness in the factories, construction sites and the number of avoidable accidents that took place daily at these places. I like to commend, of course,

Column: 427

the increase in the number of posts for the Shipbuilding and Repairing Inspections Section.

    What about having more inspectors for the factories and construction sites? Too many accidents happen at these places. Whatever has been reported to the Police or the Labour Ministry may only be a fraction compared to the real number of accidents which go unreported, Regular inspections of factories for safety measures, particularly construction sites, or violation of safety rules would help to reduce the number of accidents on human lives. Sometimes a commission of inquiry has to be set up, such as the one on the recent accident at the construction site of the Singapore Maritime Centre.

    In addition to this, the Factory lnspectorate should also hold regular campaigns and exhibitions in connection with safety measures so that the workers would be constantly reminded of the safety rules to be followed. Otherwise, we may continue `to lose valuable labour.

    The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Labour (Mr Fong Sip Chee): Mr Speaker, Sir, I must thank the Member for Moulmein for his personal compliment given me. But I feel that my staff who have spent so much time and effort in this should be congratulated for controlling industrial accidents in Singapore.

    May I at the outset take this opportunity to clarify one or two points. There has been some misconception about the term "industrial accidents". Various figures were quoted in the press from time to time. In fact, "industrial accident" means those accidents reportable under the Factories Act only, and not all other forms of accidents involved during employment which I will broadly classify as "occupational accidents". Industrial accident is not that serious as one would imagine if one were to compare the figures with the number of occupational accidents. In fact, there had been occupational accidents in Singapore ever

Column: 428

since Sir Stamford Raffles set foot on Singapore soil. I do not know whether any accident occurred during his landing.

    Sir, I am pleased to note that the NTUC has strengthened the Occupational Health and Safety Committee. This will indeed be a strong arm which can assist the Ministry to combat the common problem of industrial accidents. Unfortunately, the NTUC and the Ministry of Labour happen to be the orlly two organised bodies that are really tackling the problem. There seems to be an absence of a similar form of organisation on the part of employers, although much lip-service has been paid by employers all this while.

    The Member for Moulmein is quite correct in stating that in the construction industry the accident rate is high. I am afraid I have to agree with him, much to the dismay of the irresponsible employers. But what the Member has said is completely true: that a human being is not given the value that some employers would give to their dogs. The contractors have no excuse at all for failing to provide the various paraphernalia for industrial safety, because the cost of all these items are included in their tender quotations: these are what is known as the "Preliminaries" item. It is also augmented by another item - "prime cost" - a sum of money set for the provision of industrial safety appliances and equipment.

    Most employers, as the Member has pointed out, regard the provision of money spent on safety measures as non-productive expenses rather than as a kind of long-term investment for better returns.

    The Member for Moulmein touched on the question of loss of productivity, the loss involved in compensation and the loss of production time and cost. This is a very real problem but unfortunately most employers do not appreciate this point. Let me give a few figures to illustrate what the Member for Moulmein was trying to impress upon this House. Some figures were quoted by my Minister of State earlier on but may I repeat them for purposes of comparison.

    In 1973 the number of man-days lost due to industrial action was 2.295. During the

Column: 429

same year the number of man-days lost in industrial accidents was 549,499. The following year. 1974, the number of man-days lost due to industrial stoppages was 5.380. For the same period, the number of man-days lost due to industrial accidents was 6 16.559. In 1975, the number of man-days lost due to industrial stoppages was 4.853. The number of man-days lost due to industrial accidents in 1975 is not available but I can safely put it at plus/minus 700,000. So Hon. Members can see the vast difference between the two figures and the total loss to the economy as a whole. Of course, the individual factory suffering one accident may not see the pinch of this loss but we cannot afford, as a whole, to lose nearly - million man-days per year simply because of industrial accidents.

    We have been doing very well in the industrial accidents front and for this my Ministry has been activated to have some work-plans for this year. The work-plans have been set out to work to a certain target, but I am afraid we do have our handicaps, in terms of staffing, for example. I will handle this point when I reply to the Member for Anson.

    As I have said earlier on, the Member for Anson is probably aware that the two most accident prone industrial areas happen to be the shipbuilding and repair and the construction industries. It is because of all the experience that we have had in the past that we have set up a special unit to look after the construction industry. This unit has been in operation for several years now and it also has its own set of regulations.

    Regarding the increase of 10 posts to establish the new Shipbuilding and Repairing Inspections Section. in fact, the bodies are already there though not in full establishment. They have been there for the last one year by Establishment Warrant and the Estimates only reflect the action of the Ministry in requesting for the staff. We have assigned them to look after the Shipbuilding and Repairing Inspections Section.

    The present establishment in the Factory Inspectorate comprises 52 posts of factory inspectors and other technical staff and field

Column: 430

officers. Of these, 16 of them are in the Building and Construction Section, and 11 in the Shipbuilding and Repairing Inspections Section. The present staff strength of the Inspectorate is adequate only to carry out enforcement if we are to do only enforcement. But I do not believe at all that any unimaginative and strait-jacket enforcement is going to help the situation. Members are aware that the Factory Inspectorate is also involved in other aspects of work. It not only updates factory legislation, it is also involved in training. education, safety programmes, campaigns and providing consultation service. So you can see, Sir, if the Factory Inspectorate staff, as I said earlier, were to confine themselves to enforcement, I think they ought to be adequate. But since they have to take on the additional responsibility that I have just mentioned, they have to stretch their staff very thin. In fact, I must compliment them in that in spite of the great volume of work they have done exceptionally well.

3.00 p.m.

    The Member for Anson has also mentioned that many accidents were not reported. May I explain here that not all accidents are reported, or reportable, to the Chief Inspector of Factories. Only an accident which incapacitates a worker for more than three days is classified as a reportable accident under the Factories Act. Some accidents might have come to the knowledge of the Member for Anson. But I am afraid there is no legal requirement for employers to report all accidents to the Factory Inspectorate. Of course, they are still entitled to workmen's compensation. But not all accidents are reported. In the last two years we have improved our system of reporting. There is now a more effective system of monitoring accidents. I would say that most of the accidents which occurred are within the knowledge of the Factory Inspectorate.

    I agree with the Member for Anson that regular inspections of factories, industrial establishments, and worksites would certainly help to check accidents. In fact, in 1 975 the Factory Inspectors made a total of

Column: 431

7,118 inspections, and follow-up visits to the factories and work-places. As a result of these inspections. 5,538 cases of noncompliance with the Factories Act were detected and the employers were required to rectify the safety hazards. In addition, normal punitive action was taken against offending employers in court.

    Regular safety campaigns, as proposed by the Member for Anson, have also been conducted. For instance, the Member might know of the "Shipbuilding", "Construction" and "Safety and Health" Campaigns were launched in 1974. There were also other campaigns launched by the Ministry for a particular industry to highlight the problems peculiar to that industry. They were not general campaigns which the people concerned would find very little interest.

    The Ministry of Labour has also published a number of pamphlets and guides. Pamphlets such as the "Do you know" series to educate the workers on various hazards like explosion, fire, and health pamphlets to prevent noise-induced deafness and silicosis were distributed. The Ministry also sent out safety circulars to all the construction sites informing contractors of the latest discovery in safety hazards which some contractors may not have any knowledge of. We have also sent out safety guides, set up committees to look after peculiar problems of certain industries. I hope that with the cooperation of the employers, and I really appeal to them to be more positive, we should be able to do very much more to promote industrial health and safety. I look forward to a more solid support from the NTUC, and I take this opportunity to thank them for the help given to the Ministry of Labour all these years.

    Mr Phey Yew Kok (Boon Teck): Mr Speaker, Sir, I would also like to join in congratulating the Ministry of Labour for its success over the last two years in reducing the number of industrial accidents and taking all the necessary measures for our workers' safety. Last year work at a number of building construction sites was stopped by the

Column: 432

Ministry of Labour because of the occurrence of fatal accidents. I should say that this is most welcome. But, on the other hand, when work at the worksites stopped to enable all the precautionary measures to be taken, the workers lost their daily wages. Will the Ministry of Labour consider that, in future, when action is being taken against the employers and there is a complete stoppage of work at any worksite, whether the workers will continue to be paid?

    Mr Fong Sip Chee: Mr Speaker, Sir, I am afraid my answer will disappoint the Member for Boon Teck. Our philosophy is not to pay a person for no work done. There is a shortage of construction workers. The employers normally plead with the Ministry to allow their workers to resume work, otherwise they will run away to other worksites or even adjacent worksites. I do not think the workers really suffer because there is a shortage of construction workers. It is not the policy of the Ministry to pay workers for no work done.

    Mr Phey Yew Kok: Mr Speaker, Sir, when the Ministry directs a stoppage of construction work at the worksites, it is to ensure that all precautionary measures are taken by the employers. The workers should, therefore, not be penalised as a result of this action. It is different from other stoppages of work such as industrial action. The employers should be punished, and if the Ministry of Labour makes the employers pay for the daily wages, they will definitely try to take every precautionary measure to make sure that work can be resumed immediately.

    Mr Fong Sip Chee: Mr Speaker, Sir, it is very unfortunate that in more than half of the industrial accident cases the workers themselves were responsible. It is very difficult for our enforcement officers to lay hands on them. I must also take this opportunity to caution the workers that the Ministry would not hesitate to take whatever action necessary to bring them in line with our requirements. Most of the time we managed to catch hold of the employers because we could locate them but not the workers. If the NTUC can do their part by exhorting the workers to be more safety

Column: 433

conscious, there would be no further need for any stoppage of work at all.

    There are three aspects to safety. First, there is legislation. Second, the physical environment, that is. the provision of safety appliances and supervision which are the responsibility of the employers, and third, which is the most important, the behavioral aspect. If the employers are not keen to supervise their workers, the workers would not be keen to comply with the safety requirements. So in the end stoppage of work will not save the workers at all. As I have said, more than half of the accidents were actually due to the carelessness and even blatant defiance of safety rules on the part of the workers. They should consider themselves lucky that we have not brought them to court. More of them should be.

    Dr Augustine H. H. Tan (Whampoa): Mr Speaker, Sir, I am happy to note that the Ministry of Labour has done so much and so well in the field of workers' safety. I have just a little question to ask the Senior Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Labour. He has said just now that the Ministry of Labour has printed many pamphlets for distribution to the workers in respect of safety. I recall that two days ago in this very Chamber he complained about the high rate of illiteracy in Singapore. I am just wondering how he can get the workers to read the pamphlets?

    Mr Fong Sip Chee: There was no complaint on my part of illiteracy or the poor standard of literacy. On one occasion I did propose in jest to the former Minister for Education (I cannot remember which Minister because there have been so many changes) that they should call themselves the "Ministry of Literacy" and let the Ministry of Culture undertake the educational aspect. But the Ministry of Culture appears to be equally unacceptable to me to play this role. There is no question of the workers being unable to read the pamphlets which have been written in the simplest form. I do not think we can simplify it any further.

    Dr Augustine Tan: In Hokkien then.

    Mr Fong Sip Chee: Well, Hokkien is not a

Column: 434

written language. Hokkien can be romanised but it might become a Frankenstein of a language.

    Dr Ong Leong Boon (Kim Seng): Mr Speaker, Sir, I rise to support the request of the Member for Boon Teck. I am not at all impressed with the reply given by the Senior Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Labour. The Member for Boon Teck said that where there is a failure to provide adequate safety measures leading to work stoppage and where the fault lies with the employers, then the workers should not be penalised. This is the point which I would like to emphasise: if it was the fault of the workers that the work had stopped, then it is surely reasonable and fair that the workers should be deprived of their pay. But if, on the other hand, it is the failure of the employers to provide the necessary safety measures, then I believe the Ministry of Labour should ensure that the employers be made to comply with the safety regulations by providing precautionary measures, and for any number of days in which work had stopped the employers should be made to pay the workers, because the workers are not responsible for the provision of these safety measures but the employers. I would like to have his considered reply once again, and if it is not satisfactory we shall pursue it further.

    Mr Ivan Baptist (Potong Pasir): Mr Speaker. Sir, the Senior Parliamentary Secretary has mentioned that the workers are mainly responsible for accidents due to their negligence, carelessness, etc. May I correct him and say that from the Ministry of Labour's statistics it is due to a lack of knowledge. It was precisely for this reason that regulations were introduced with effect from 1st December, 1975, for safety committees to be set up to ensure that employers take cognisance of the fact that a lack of knowledge exists and that members of the safety committees should be educated to enable them to know more about safety. In addition, there should be provision for the adequate education of the workers at the factory floor level. I would also add that the employers too lack knowledge on occupational health and safety. I feel that this

Column: 435

is of paramount importance for Government to stress.

    I do not know what plans are afoot, but I believe that the 77 personnel in the Factory Inspectorate will not be sufficient to go around enforcing legislation. Time and time again I have made the point that we will need an army of inspectors for the more than 5,000 factories in Singapore. Therefore, self-regulatory measures should be introduced in addition to the creation of enthusiasm, and education, which is covered by the Factories Act and enforcement.     For some years now the HDB has been invariably chaired by a private individual working on a part-time basis, but for the time being the Permanent Secretary of the Ministry is the acting Chairman. I do hope that this will become a permanent feature as by having direct control of the activities of the `Board by a senior Government officer. there will be numerous advantages. First, there is greater awareness and appreciation of the thinking of the political leadership. Secondly, being a senior Government officer, he can more easily coordinate the activities of the Board with those of the other Government departments - from overall planning down to day-to-day administration.

    Greater coordination will go a long way towards ensuring unnecessary wastage, delays and, above all. comprehensiveness in services. The apparent lack of comprehensiveness in planning resulting from lack of proper coordination has given rise to a number of anomalies and shortcomings. Take, for example, Toa Payoh, a town of not less than a quarter million people. There was not a police station in sight when it was first completed. In no time it was to acquire the dubious reputation of being the Chicago of Singapore. Another example is to be found in the location of the Jalan Kayu Post Office at the newly completed HDB estate. This post office is tucked away in such an odd and inconspicuous corner some distance away from the market and shopping centre. The explanation given to me was that the requirement of the post office was not taken into consideration at the planning stage. By the time the post office asked for a suitable site, all shop premises had been taken up. In planning the estate, it is also obvious to me that no attention was paid to the unavoidable impact on the traffic situation in the neighbourhood resulting from overnight expansion in population. This has caused serious congestion and increasing number of road accidents at the traffic junction close by. Many will obviously like to decentralise their services by setting up offices or sub-offices in newly established population centres so as to provide on-the-spot service and in the process help to alleviate the serious problem of traffic congestion in the Central Business District, where most of them are situated at present. Minister explained earlier, which determines the level of rentals and the Board obviously takes the view that if people want to pay more and in the process kill themselves, it is their own business, let them.
